Posts.Title: Others who are triple negative - how long on chemo? TNIV menan

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 05:12PM bottkota wrote: All great questions....let's see if I can do them any justice!  ;) 1.) Can you tell us a little about where you live in South Dakota and what would you recommend as some of the tops things to do there and in the surrounding area? I live in the southern eastern tip of South Dakota...close to the Minnesota border.  On our half of the state there is pretty much nothing to do nor any sites to see....it's boring over here!  BUT....on the western half of the state is BEAUTIFUL!  It is covered with hills and trees...hence the name it gets...Black Hills!  They look black!  I love it over there.  My brother lives there and so we have a chance to visit him and also sight see if we choose!  There is Mount Rushmore, Bear Country, Reptile Gardens, the Badlands...ect.  There is also the Sturgis Bike Rally in Sturgis every summer (huge attration for motorcycle lovers).  There is also skiing, snowboarding, hiking and camping that you can do.  If I could....I would live in Western South Dakota!  But my husband's job is here so we just visit and dream about living there! :) 2.) You have young children. How old are they?  How have they handled the different stages of your cancer journey from initial diagnosis, to mets and now NED? Any advice to other moms of young kids/teens? My kids are 17 (Briana), 12 (Mikayla), 10 (Colby) and 8 (Keara).  They were only 9, 4, 2 and almost 1 when I was first diagnosed!  Keara was just 10 days away from her 1st birthday.  And actually her first birthday I was in the hospital recovering from my double mastectomy!  So they were really young to understand what having cancer was all about.  I did the chemo and all that and we went on with our lives until Nov. 2009 when my cancer returned, by now they were 14, 9, 6 and 5.  They were scared now....we shed many tears....and my son feared that he was losing me.  We just took it one day at a time and put our hope and trust in the Lord and lived each day to the fullest.  It took almost 2 years before we reached NED and they have been excited that each scan has proven no cancer!  They are hopefully....but still have their fears....but I guess there is always that fear.  My husband and I have always been up front and honest with what goes one with me.  We don't want our children to ever wonder why we didn't keep them informed of things.  So we do our best to keep them up to speed in terms that they can understand.  Like last month when we sat them down and told them that I had quit chemo and was just doing the research drug.  They all had that scared look in their eyes....to them quiting chemo means death.  We told them that was not the case.  I needed a break and let my body heal itself so that when it comes back I will be a lot stronger to endure chemo again. Again we live each day to the fullest and enjoy each moment and memory! My advice to other moms with young kids/teens....love those kids as much as you can while you can!  Make LOTS of memories!  But don't be hard on yourself when you don't feel well enough to do something or be there for an event.  They will understand...probably not right away but when they are older they will get it!  Hugs, kisses and everything else! 3.) For which TNBC drug or combination of drugs have you been on a clinical trial?  Are you still on one?  What was your experience like? I started a clinical trial of Avastin, Abraxane and Gemzar when I was diagnosed with mets in Nov. 2009.  It really put a sock on my mets....nearly wiping it all out except for one stubborn node in my brachial plexus.  I was removed from Avastin in June 2010 due to a bladder infection and I truly believe that is why I progressed just 3 short months later.  The cancer got funny and moved to my liver with two small lesions.  I knew there was a PARP inhibitor trial down in Sioux City, Iowa that I could possibly qualify for.  So began my waiting and waiting and waiting some more.  This was no normal trial, instead it was an expanded access protocol with a "lottery".  Which meant my name went into a pool and was randomly drawn.  in the meantime....my cancer went out of control.  My liver was starting to be over taken with new tumors and the node in my brachial plexus was breaking out of its capsule.  So I did radiation to my chest and braxial while I waited.  My name was finally drawn and I started Carbo/Gemzar/Iniparib (BSI-201) in Nov. 2010, two months after we learned the cancer was in my liver.  That is the protocol I am still on today.  I acheived NED in Sept. 2011 and have remained that way since.  In Sept. 2012, we had to drop the gemzar because of low blood counts and just last month I chose to drop the carbo.  I will have a scan next month to see if the Iniparib alone has been enough to keep me NED!  I don't mind clinical trials...and they monitor you very carefully!  The only downside....taking a break is pretty hard to do, without getting off the trial.  So while I am doing someone in the future something good....some days are hard.... 4.) What is your favorite dessert and if it's something you make yourself, can you share the recipe? HMMMMM.....my favorite dessert would be my mom's homemade brownie recipe!  I LOVE chocolate and these satisfy the sweet tooth.  What is the best with them....warmed up, with some vanilla ice cream and chocolate syrup!  YUMMY!!!  here is the recipe:                        Bring to a boil: 2 sticks of butter, 1 cup of water and 4 tablespoons of cocoa.  Then add 2 cups flour, 2 cups sugar and mix well.  Then add 1/2 cup buttermilk (I make my own buttermilk, 1 cup milk with 1 tablespoon of vinegar, let sit for about 10 min), 2 eggs, 1 teaspoon soda and 1 teaspoon vanilla.  Mix well.  Bake at 400 degrees for about 20 minutes in a greased cookie sheet.  :) The Brownie frosting is made this way: in a small saucepan heat to a boil: 1 stick butter, 1/3 cup buttermilk, 1/4 cup cocoa.  Remove from heat and add 3 1/2 cup powdered sugar and 1 teaspoon vanilla.  Spread on brownies! THESE ARE THE BEST!!!!!  :) FATTENING....BUT TO DIE FOR!!!! 5.) If you were to win a prize of the party of your dreams, where would you hold it and what specifically would you request for type of food and entertainment? Well.....let's see....this is a tough one!  I guess a party of my dreams would be on the beach somewhere (I am not picky as long as it is a beach with an ocean).  Food would be lots and lots of dessert...cake, cookies, brownies and anything loaded with sugar but even more....smores over an open campfire....oh yeah!, along with that probably finger sandwiches with ham and turkey in them, pototao salad, plus lots of alcohol!  Beer, wine and Mike's Hard lemonade...mixed winter berry!  And entertainment would have to be some good dance music so we can dance and party under the stars all night long!   I hope that this gives everyone a better idea of who I am.  I don't post a lot but I sure do read a lot!  I have found some very inspirational women on this board!  I think I know who my next pick is....if she is ok with it!  Will need to PM her and ask her!  Plus come up with some questions!  It will probably be tomorrow afternoon before I get some questions done!  Thanks HeidiHill for the opportunity!  I appreciate it! Cathi
Posts.Title: Five Questions: Bottkota Heidihill exbrnxgrl

But then again I am biased! ;)

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 07:07PM bottkota wrote: Dell....this was my first scan that showed NED....all other scans have showed improvement in all areas...my PET in Feb. 2011 showed NED in my liver but lymph nodes were still lighting up....plus I had TONS of inflammation from the radiation that I had in Nov of 2010 so they couldn't say whether it was cancer or not!  Thankfully this scan showed NED!!!!  I will be on this protocol a year on Nov. 15th....I am not sure how long I will remain on the protocol.  That is what is so hard about future planning.  I know at some point my body will become toxic and I will have to do something.  My body has a hard time right now rebounding.  I just finished cycle 16 yesterday...I have next week off....which I need as my platelets as of yesterday were 62 and my hemoglobin was below 9.  My counts don't rebound a lot on my weeks off but enough to get full dose chemo....we have only had to delay treatment once.  I think the next scan will determine what we do going forward.  It is so hard to know if it's the 3 drugs together that are giving me NED or 1 or 2 or the Inipirib, ect.  What does your doctor say?  How long do you think you will stay on it?  Sooooo very happy to hear that things are still working for you and for you too Nicole!  YEAH FOR INIPIRIB!!!  ;) Cathi
Posts.Title: Encouraging PARP news nmiller1978 bottkota

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 06:53AM bottkota wrote: I too am on the same treatment for my stage 4 cancer and I learned on the 12th of Sept that I am also NED!!!!  It was the best news ever!  So we have chosen to stay on the protocol....who would want to go off something if it is working?  I am glad that even though they closed the EAP....that those of us that it was working for we allowed to continue to stay on it!  I started cycle 16 this week....I have been on this protocol for almost a year (Nov. 15, 2010 I started).  I hope my next scan before Christmas continues to show NED!!!  I have both BRCA 1 & 2 mutations.....I am unique!  But that's ok.....I am NED and that's what matters most!  So glad that others are having as much success as me on this protocol!!!  Cathi

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 01:14PM bottkota wrote: Hello all!  I am going to be starting chemo for bone mets hopefully next week.  My path report is the same as my first cancer 4 1/2 years ago.  Triple Negative.  I am going on a clinical trial through the Mayo clinic.  Here are my 3 drugs, can anyone give me some advice?  I am scared of what side effects they will bring and if they will drag me down more than the AC and Taxol treatments did the first time around.  I am on a 21 day cycle.  Day 1 Abraxane, Gemzar and Avastin; Day 8 Abraxane and Gemzar, rest from avastin.  Week 3 total rest from all chemo.  I know the side effects for all of them but really want to know if anyone has had all 3 drugs. or 2 of the 3 given.  If I have to go off the study because the side effects are too great, my oncologist said that he would be putting me on Taxol and something else (I don't remember what drug, mad that my cancer has come back after all this time).  has anyone overhauled there diet and eaten more fruits and veggies and had good results along with chemo????  I am grasping at anything right now.  I am only 35 with 4 children still at home, the youngest of which is 5.  I homeschool them also so I am not afraid of them bringing home the flu or anything like that to my already compromised immune system.  Any advice?  Glad there is a thread for me to vent to especially after I start treatments.  UGH!  cancer really sucks!

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2017 12:02AM bottkota wrote: I was diagnosed stage 4 November 2, 2009. I have been on several different treatments thru the years but since April of 2014, I have been on the parp inhibitor Veliparib, 4 pills twice daily, every day, no breaks. No real side effects except my sleep pattern seems to be all haywire, but I blame a lot of that on my personal life being a mess more than the pills. Anyway, my QOL is pretty good. I finally have more energy to do things around the house and live life. I am 42, carry both BRCA mutations and was first diagnosed stage 2 6 months before my 31st Birthday! Triple neg from the beginning and I need recurrence. 7 1/2 years and still going strong.  Cathi

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2011 08:34AM bottkota wrote: I have been dealing with mets since November 2nd of 2009.  So 22 months for me.  As a triple neg....I hate to read stats......but I am only on my 2nd line of therapy and my recent PET and dedicated CT results on Monday showed NED!!!  So I am continuing with Gem/Carbo/Inipirib....hoping to stay NED for a very long time!  I had 4 1/2 years between first diagnosis and mets all though we think I was living with mets for about a year before it was discovered.  Mets started in sternum and surrounding lymph nodes and then last Sept. it moved to my liver.....Feb of 2011 my liver was NED and just this month whole body NED.....I plan to be here a long time!  We have to make up the positive side of a stat so they can have their average number!  Let's keep up the good work ladies and get those stats to reflect that many many women are living longer with their stage 4 diagnosis!  We aren't giving up and playing dead....we are fighting and winning!!!  Thanks for the inspiration!! Cathi

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2012 06:32AM bottkota wrote: I am currently getting gemzar/carbo/BSI-201.  I am on cycle 21 (15 months on this protocol) and my only complaint is the run down sick to my stomach feeling after days 1 and 8.  So I get all three drugs on days 1 and 8 and just the BSI on days 4 and 11.  then I get a week off.  This treatment has brought me to NED as of Sept. 2011.  I asked my oncologist yesterday about eliminating the gem/carbo and he was not in favor of it.  So even though I am tired, run down, I have to dig deep and keep running as long as I can on this protocol!  :(  In the begining it wasn't so bad...but the further I get into it, the harder it is!  My counts are starting to tank out and my platelets are having the hardest time rebounding!  I have had 2 dose reductions of gemzar and a just a few delays in treatment!  I think that carbo/cis are similar, because they are both part of the paltinum family.  Good luck with you new treatment!  BTW....I have been on gemzar since November 2009, I had it with my first protocol (gem/abrax/avastin) worked 9 months until it moved into my liver.  So I have had a great run on this protocol....just tired of it!  And my hair has been growing not a lot but some!  I can at least go without something on my head, if I choose....the only bad thing....it is GREY :(,  I am only 37.....sigh Cathi

Posts.Content: bottkota wrote: I have just recently found out that my cancer has returned after 4 1/2 years of being with NED!!!  UGH!  Anyway....my oncologist is wanting to get me into this Mayo clinic research group for chemo.  I am wondering if anyone else could possibly be in this study or know of anyone in this study.  The drug cocktail is Abraxane, Gamzar and Avastin.  1 week all three drugs, 2 week no Gemzar and week 3 resting.  My return of my cancer is in my sternum and surrounding lymph nodes.  Praises that it is no where else, according to the PET scan anyways.  Not really sure I want to do the study program.  Not wanting to be a "lab rat"!  Anyone have any advice for me?  Could you some right now.  Really wishing I wasn't going to be battling this beast again!  I thought once was enough!  I was only 30 when I was diagnosed.   Do you ever sometimes ask "why me???"  I HATE this disease!  It took my grandmother, my cousin, thankfully my mother has been cancer free for like 25 years.  I wish I was like her, still cancer free.  Thanks for listening!  This SUCKS! Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 09:33AM bottkota wrote: my oncologist worked her butt off to get me the drug on compassionate use. She was give the option either higher dose without chemo or lower dose with chemo. And since the chemo drug they were talking she had to use is for brain cancer and wouldn't be covered by my insurance she went with the higher dose as monotherapy. My onc also opened up a clinical trial in her office for me to get this drug. That is why it has taken months for approval. We have been trying since the first part of October. I am just trying to find someone who is on it as a single agent to talk with about side effects, which I know are better than chemo.  Tonya.....keep on keepin on!!  I love to hear about others who are still on gem/carbo/Iniparib.  I have my thoughts as well that I don't think Iniparib worked for me without chemo. The combo got me to NED but after I let go of the chemo Iniparib just couldn't keep me NED....took 9 months for the cancer to come back so that's a good thing. I just keep moving along and trusting The Lord for each day! Cathi

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 08:38PM bottkota wrote: I am going on a clinical trial through the Mayo Clinic.  It is Abraxane, Gemzar and Avastin.  It seems promising to me and I am holding onto any and all promising drug regimines!  I am not wanting to do this again but need to in order to stick around to see my kids grown.  My youngest is 5 1/2.  She turned 1 10 days after I was diagnosed the first time around.  Really want to be around for all of them for many more years.  Hoping this will do the trick!  Along with a diet and exercise overhaul.  Guess it is time to take care of my body.  Wish I had stuck with taking care of it after my first round with cancer.  Oh well, can't change it now, it is back and I need to fight it off again!  I guess I will live with another week of "normalcy"  lucky me!!  lol

Posts.Content: bottkota wrote: was wondering if someone could tell me why my platelets are tanking?  I am currently on Gemzar/Carbo/PARP BSI-201 have been on this since November 15th and haven't had a problem till now with my platelets.  Last Monday my platelets were 150, Thursday they were 112 and yesterday when I had them rechecked (I am off treatment this week) they were 47....Good gravy, what in the hell is going on?  I will have them rechecked on Friday but if they don't rebound by Monday, I won't get treatment....well I don't want that.  Is there anything that I can do here at home to make those platelets rebound?  I am worried about a "new" cancer or something else really horrible going on inside my body.  This whole things just SUCKS!!!  I don't post often but I do check in to see how everyone is doing.  Thoughts on the platelets?  Don't want to give up on this treatment as it has only been 2 months, I got 10 months on my last regiment of Abraxane, Avastin and Gemzar.  UGH!!!!  Don't want to lose the PARP....I am triple negative AND BRCA 1 & 2 positive.....this has to work for me.....thanks again!! Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer with mets to lung and bones malayli bottkota

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2015 05:55PM bottkota wrote: I am BRCA 1 and 2 positive. I am also triple negative. When my cancer first came back in 2009 (after a 4 1/2 year remission) my onc (who I "fired" 10 months later) didn't really do anything as far as my BRCA status or my triple neg but put me in a trial of his own. It worked for 10 months and the cancer spread to my liver. I found a new onc who fought tooth and nail to get me into a trial with then PARP Iniparib along with chemo. That was my saving grace. That drug along with gem/carbo put me into NED for almost 2 years. 2 months shy of my 3 year mark of the trial, my cancer again reared it's head in my liver. I was dropped from the trial and did carbo/gem alone for 6 months while my onc again fought tooth and nail to get me compassionate use veliparib, which I started in April 2014. She felt strongly that PARP's were good for my cancer she also feels that my BRCA status also plays a role into why they work so well for me. I am still on veliparib as a single agent for just a little over a year. I am grateful for my onc because I honestly believe I wouldn't be here still if I hadn't fought for myself and what I wanted. And a PARP is what I was wanting to get on for a long time before I did actually get on one.  Cathi

Posts.Title: Triple Negative Only Renae64 11tyBillion

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 09:00AM bottkota wrote: Add me as well. Original diagnosis Apr. 2005 stage 2 no node involvement. Nov 2009 mets to sternum and surrounding lymph nodes. Did abraxane, Gemzar and avastin for 10 months...then the cancer got sneaky and moved to my liver. While waiting for my name to be drawn for an expanded access trial, I did 5 radiation treatments to my sternum and brachial plexus. Name was drawn for trial and began carbo, Gemzar and iniparib (former PARP inhibitor) in Nov. 2010. Have been on it ever since. Reached NED in sept. 2011 and have maintained it since. Stopped Gemzar in sept. 2012 due to low platelets and stopped carbo in jan, because my body is tired....and breaking down. Doing iniparib only right now, hoping it will keep me NED. I am also braca 1 and 2 positive. And have a HUGE family history. :/. Cathi

Posts.Title: Redwolf, Penny, is an angel! bottkota celia088

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2012 04:41PM bottkota wrote: I have been on carbo and Gemzar since nov. 2010 and we just recently dropped Gemzar. Also get BSI-201 which used to be classified as a PARP inhibitor but not anymore. I have hair and it actually grows enough where I get it cut every 6 weeks. When I started on this protocol I had just a little bit of hair, like a GI Jane look and I kept it that way for about a year then I got it cut and styled last Oct. for the first time since my stage 4 diagnosis and I have been doing it ever since. You won't lose your hair....if you do, I will be shocked!!! Also the carbo gives me minimal side effects, a lot of my side effects were from the steroid and the Gemzar. We stopped the steroid on Monday when I had treatment and I feel like I didn't even have treatment on Monday. I hope you get awesome results from this trial. I am currently NED and have been for a year now. Cathi
Posts.Title: CLINICAL TRIAL; includes a PARP inhibitor? Also Carboplatin mkk050709 Woodylb

Posts.Content: bottkota wrote: Sorry for the delay.....I am still processing this... NED....CLEAR.....NEGATIVE!!!! 15 months of NED so far....I am excited, grateful and everything in between. Talked with my oncologist about stopping the carbo and just doing iniparib. She left it up to me...so we decided to continue the course and then decide after the first of the year. In the meantime...I am going to pray for clear direction. My 4th rib has a fracture but it is not from the cancer. I am thinking it is from my frozen shoulder and physical therapy....it is on the side that is frozen. Who knows tho'!! I will be talking to my physical therapist when I see her on Tuesday!! This was by far the best early Christmas present I could even ask for or receive!!!! Cathi Dx 11/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Any advice....want to make a clear and informed decision.....the list of side effects scares me. There is an increased risk of MDS as well.  Thanks! Posts.Title: Veliparib bottkota bottkota

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 02:17PM bottkota wrote: Christy ~ thank you for getting back to me about veliparib. I am sorry to hear about your progression. So you got about 7 months on the drug? You also mentioned that you had some problems with your platelets? What is the lowest they ever got and did you ever need a platelet transfusion? Gemzar and carbo are trashing my platelets and hemoglobin. I am on a 3 week chemo break right now and need to make a decision about the veliparib before the 31st when I see my onc again. My platelets bottomed out at 10,000 the 5th of March and my hemoglobin bottomed out at 6.7 so had to get blood, too. My body is tired. How often did you have labs done? Just every 28 days? How can they keep track of what your counts are doing. I just don't know what to do, I am very confused. And I haven't been able to find anyone else on this drug which is hard to talk with others about it, glad that I least found you. :) I am triple negative and carry both BRCA 1 & 2 genes.  Right now my cancer is very small, the chemo has kicked cancers ass but it has also kicked mine as well. Just need to know what the right thing to do would be. And I don't have a lot of time to make that decision. Do you regret your decision to go on the drug? Thanks again for letting me know. Sorry again that it stopped working for you. :( what are you going on now for treatment?   Cathi
Posts.Title: Veliparib bottkota bottkota

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 06:02PM bottkota wrote: Christy ~ thank you so much for getting back to me. I hope the carbo will kick cancers butt right out of your body. I truly believe in the platinum drugs....carbo has done wonders against my cancer of course it has been with Gemzar too. Have you has those two as a combo??  I think carbo is way gentler on counts then gem. So here's to a little luck with it. Side effects are pretty good too. A little nausea the first 2 days after chemo a slight headache and that is about it. Pretty mild. 20+ months is a long time on a drug....that gives me a little bit of hope. I have to make my final decision by tomorrow so the research nurse has some time to get the drug to the cancer center by the following week. I am hoping that if I make the decision to go on the drug that it will be nicer to my platelets than the chemo was.  Thank you so much for all your input....it has been very helpful. I wish you the best of luck with carbo!!! I hope it kicks ass HARD!!!! Cathi
Posts.Title: Veliparib bottkota bottkota

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2012 08:02AM bottkota wrote: Thanks.....as I don't have anything pink, nor does my husband or son...we decided that we would do a pink ribbon on our shirts. My youngest daughter LOVES pink and will be decked out in pink, my two oldest don't like pink for other reasons, so they will have the ribbon as well. I didn't want to go buy pink but really wanted to honor her in some way, so a pink ribbon is the best i can do. It is about her and only her on Saturday. I will keep my thoughts and opinions to myself unless the door is opened for a discussion. And yes, she died because of the IBC. her last scan earlier this month showed tumors all over her body, plus she was going once a week or so to have her lungs drained. She entered hospice last Friday and died on Sunday. So fast...but such a fighter all the way!! Thanks again for the advice. Cathi
Posts.Title: Funeral on Saturday and asked to wear pink.... bottkota

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 04:11PM bottkota wrote: Hi Ren!  I am triple neg with mets to my lymph nodes/sternum.  I have been fighting this for 6 months now and my chemo is working in my favor and really kicking my cancer.  I am pretty close to NED.  have you looked into the PARPS???  Those are showing some good promise for us triple negs but I also know there are chemos to try as well.  I am not able to get into a trial with the PARPS because I have no measurable disease.  Does your onc have a plan of action yet?  I would do lots and lots of research.  Wish I had done as much research in the beginning of this as I have been doing the last several months.  There is a lot to know....don't give up hope....it is what we have to cling too.....PM me if you ever want to talk.  I have 4 young kids at home that I am fighting to see grown....they are the reason I endure all the agony I do..... Cathi
Posts.Title: Triple negative with mets JerseyMom cwrightrn

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2012 10:59AM bottkota wrote: Hi!  I am here still fighting TN mets.....27 months later!  Currently NED but still doing treatment.  NEVER let anyone tell you how long you have to live....last time I checked there is only 1 God and He is in control.  Our doctor's can give us an idea....but even they don't know.  Everyone responds to treatment differently.  Us trip negs to band together and defy those stupid stats!  let's be part of the positive side of those numbers....because really someone has to be part of the positive to get there average numbers, right?  so let's be those positives!  :)  hang in there. Cathi

Posts.Title: Funeral on Saturday and asked to wear pink.... bottkota

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2012 05:37AM bottkota wrote: I have been at this almost 3 years and I have watched what it has done to me and my family. Just last night we had a 'round table' discussion with our 4 kids. I have been on the same clinical trial for almost 2 years and we are now seeing the chemo taking its toll on my counts. My platelets were 34,000 yesterday, have to take another week off of chemo, my body just can't recover anymore in one short week. We asked what the kids thought about me going off one drug or both drugs and just getting the research drug. There was mixed thoughts of course. Kids think no chemo....mom dies. We have a huge decision to make and not an easy one at that. I truly hate this disease and what it does to us and our families. Those of us that walk this road...get it. Others.....not so much. So hard.....chin up girl and keep on fighting. I believe my children are worth the pain and suffering...to get one more day, week, month or year to see them grow. Cathi
Posts.Title: Why do we fight so hard? SPAMgirl Amyf

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 12:24PM bottkota wrote: hi Amy!  statistics are scary aren't they?  I am also triple negative, diagnosed 4 1/2 years ago and got the slap in the face last month with the diagnosis of mets to my sternum and surrounding lymph nodes.  Thankfully my onc didn't tell me how long I would survive (i have been doing my own research and don't like looking at those stats) but if he had I would be looking for another onc.  We need to fight the good fight for all it's worth.  I started chemo (abraxane, gemzar and avastin) on November 20th.  I have chemo 1x a week for 2 weeks and then off on week 3.  start the cycle all over again.  i will be on chemo until it stops working, then i will go on to the next available drug.  don't give up and don't look at stats (they are scary enough as it is).  think of your daughter and keep plugging away!  None of us know when our time here on earth is up, only the Good Lord knows and until that time, keep fighting!  NEVER give up hope.  new drugs and such are coming out all the time.  this SUCKS!!!  I have 4 kids myself with my youngest being 5 1/2.  She was almost 1 when I was first diagnosed!  They are the reason that I am fighting this (not to mention, I am only 35), I am planning on being around for many many more years!  And you will too!  If you want to talk feel free to PM me!  Take care and hold your head high and fight with all your might!  :) Cathi
Posts.Title: stage 4 peritineal metastisis help Amy1971 dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 09:06AM bottkota wrote: I have been on 2 clinical trials since being diagnosed with mets. My first one the only thing my insurance/I had to pay for was my blood draws, sitting in the infusion chair and all tests/ scans. The protocol that I am on now I or my insurance have to pay for everything except the research drug that I am on. I think each trial is different. I love clinical trials but also hate how much then confine you to the regiment. Very hard to get chemo breaks when on a trial. :/ Cathi
Posts.Title: Who's doing a clinical trial? LuvRVing LuvRVing
